'''Nexenta OS''', officially known as the '''Nexenta Core Platform''', is a computer [[operating system]] based on [[OpenSolaris]] and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] that runs on [[IA-32]]- and [[x86-64]]-based systems. It emerged in fall 2005, after [[Sun Microsystems]] started the [[OpenSolaris]] project in June of that year.<ref>[http://milek.blogspot.com/2005/12/nexentaos.html Milek's blog]</ref> Version 1.0 was released in February 2008. Nexenta Core Platform is the first operating system to combine the OpenSolaris [[kernel (computer science)|kernel]] with [[GNU]] [[userland (computing)|userland]] tools. It aims to bring technologies such as [[ZFS]] and [[Solaris Containers|Zones]] to the [[GNU]]/[[Debian]] community. An additional purpose of the OS is to provide a kernel allowing proprietary closed source hardware drivers to be produced for inclusion in an [[open source]] operating system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linux.com/articles/55120|title=NexentaOS has a chance to succeed on a Desktop|publisher=Linux.com|date=June 16, 2006}}</ref> Nexenta Systems, Inc. initiated the project and sponsors its continued development.
== Repositories == There were initially two official [[Advanced Packaging Tool|APT]] repositories: "testing" and "unstable", totalling over 9000 packages. A third "stable" was added for the first official release. Nexenta OS is available as InstallCD and [[VMware]] images. A [[Live CD]] is also available, but only for releases up to alpha 5.
Nexenta repositories follow the general Debian structure (main contrib non-free). Stable releases use a subset of this structure. Packages originate from Debian GNU/Linux.
== Development == Since Nexenta OS does not use the [[Linux kernel]], and [[Sun Microsystems|Sun]] only recently began releasing the code of their [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] operating system as [[free software|free]] and [[open source software]], it supports less diverse hardware than other [[Debian]] variants.
The Nexenta OS team has decided to focus on a minimal GNU/OpenSolaris effort called the Nexenta Core Platform (NCP)<ref name=ncp>{{cite web|url=https://www.opensolaris.org/jive/thread.jspa?threadID=32407&tstart=0|title=Announcing NexentaCP(b65) with ZFS/Boot integrated installer}}</ref> which forms the basis of the [[NexentaStor]] NAS storage solution. Version 1.0 of Nexenta Core Platform was released on February 10, 2008.
== Releases == * Nexenta Core Platform 1.0 was released on February 10, 2008. It was based on Ubuntu 6.06 "Dapper Drake" and OpenSolaris b82.<ref>{{cite mailing list|first=Alex|last=Ross|title=Nexenta Core Platform 1.0 available|mailinglist=gnusol-devel|date=February 10, 2008|url=http://lists.sonic.net/pipermail/gnusol-devel/2008-February/000958.html|accessdate=May 25, 2011}}</ref> The release included: ** [[ZFS]] root/boot ** [[Solaris Containers|zones]] integrated with [[dpkg]]/[[apt-get]] ** [[branded zones|brandz]] with preconfigured support for [[Debian]] and [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] ** stable toolchain ** server/storage software support ** [[Xen]] [[DomU]]/[[Dom0]] * Nexenta Core Platform 2.0 was released on May 25, 2009. It included packages based on Ubuntu 8.04 "Hardy Heron" LTS.<ref>{{cite mailing list|last=Gulecha|first=Anil|title=Nexenta Core Platform 2 Released|mailinglist=gnusol-devel|date=May 25, 2009|url=http://lists.sonic.net/pipermail/gnusol-devel/2009-May/001429.html|accessdate=May 25, 2011}}</ref> * Nexenta Core Platform 3.0.1 was released on September 17, 2010. The release included many updated packages, support for ZFS deduplication, and Crossbow support, among other fixes.<ref name="DW">{{cite web|url=http://distrowatch.com/?newsid=06279|title=Distribution Release: Nexenta Core Platform 3.0.1|accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref>
==NexentaStor== '''NexentaStor''' is a proprietary operating system built by Nexenta Systems on top of the Nexenta Core Platform. It is optimized for use in virtualized server environments including [[Network-attached storage|NAS]], [[iSCSI]], and [[Fibre Channel]] applications, and is built around the [[ZFS]] file system. It features [[iSCSI]] support, unlimited incremental backups or 'snapshots', snapshot mirroring (replication), block level mirroring ([[Continuous data protection|CDP]]), integrated search within ZFS snapshots and a custom API. Through its focus on ZFS, it carries with it potential benefits for virtualized server farms in terms of performance and [[thin provisioning]]. The operating system is currently distributed as [[ISO 9660|ISO]] and [[VMware]] [[disk image]]s with pricing determined on a per-terabyte and per-server licensing basis.<ref>http://www.nexenta.com/corp/?option=com_content&task=view&id=177&Itemid=119</ref>
A "community edition" is available free of charge for users with less than 18 terabyte of used disk space.<ref>http://www.nexenta.com/corp/nexentastor-overview/nexentastor-versions</ref> It is the same as the enterprise version, except for the lack of paid plugins and commercial support. It can install many of the free and open source plugins that are developed and hosted on the community edition website.
